page.title: 2008â09 Atlantic Coast Conference men's basketball season

{{Infobox sports season | title =2008â09 Atlantic Coast Conference Men's Basketball Season | color =#072E67 | color text =#EFE3BB | league =[[NCAA]] Division I | sport =[[College basketball|Basketball]] | logo = | pixels =125px | caption = | duration =December 17, 2008
through March 8, 2009 | no_of_teams =12 | attendance = | TV =[[Raycom Media|Raycom]], [[ESPN]] | draft = | draft_link = | top_pick = | picked_by = | season = Regular Season | season_champs = North Carolina (13â3) | season_champ_name= Champion | league_champs = Wake Forest (11â5)
Duke (11â5) | league_champ_name= Runners-Up | second_place = | MVP = [[Ty Lawson]] â UNC | MVP_link = ACC Men's Basketball Player of the Year | top_scorer = [[Tyler Hansbrough]] â UNC | top_scorer_link = | promote = | promoted_from = | relegate = | relegate_to = | playoffs = | playoffs_link = | conf1 = | conf1_link = | conf1_champ = | conf1-runner-up = | conf2 = | conf2_link = | conf2_champ = | conf2-runner-up = | playoffs_MVP = | playoffs_MVP_link= | finals = Tournament | finals_link = 2009 ACC Men's Basketball Tournament | finals_champ = Duke (17th) | finals-runner-up = Florida State | finals_MVP = [[Jon Scheyer]] | finals_MVP_link = Most Valuable Player | seasonslist = | seasonslistnames =Basketball | prevseason_link = | prevseason_year =[[2007â08 Atlantic Coast Conference men's basketball season|2007â08]] | nextseason_link = | nextseason_year =[[2009â10 Atlantic Coast Conference men's basketball season|2009â10]] }} {{2008â09 ACC men's basketball standings}} The '''2008â09 [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] men's basketball season''' was the 56th season for the league. North Carolina won the regular season crown while Duke won the ACC Tournament championship. The season saw [[Tyler Hansbrough]] set conference records in points (finishing with 2,872 for his career) and free throws made (982), while Miami's [[Jack McClinton]] ended his career as the conference's all time three-point marksman (.440 3-point FG%). ==Pre-season== On October 26, for the second-straight year North Carolina was the unanimous choice to finish first atop the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball race in voting by 40 media members at the leagueâs annual Basketball Media Day. Duke was picked for second, while Wake Forest was voted third. Miami was fourth, followed by Clemson (fifth) and Virginia Tech (sixth). [[Tyler Hansbrough]] was selected as pre-season ACC Player of the Year. Hansbrough averaged 22.6 points and 10.2 rebounds during the 2008â09 while earning first-team All-America honors for a third-straight year and consensus National Player of the Year honors. Wake Forest's [[Al-Farouq Aminu]] was the mediaâs choice for the ACC pre-season Rookie of the Year. Hansbrough and Boston Collegeâs [[Tyrese Rice]] were unanimous selections for the pre-season All-ACC team. Also named to the pre-season team were Miamiâs [[Jack McClinton]], North Carolinaâs [[Ty Lawson]] and [[Gerald Henderson]] from Duke. On November 13, the [[Los Angeles Athletic Club]] released their annual pre-season [[John R. Wooden Award]] watch list.{{cite web | url=http://woodenaward.cstv.com/ot/0809-mens-candidates.html | work= | publisher=Wooden Award | title=2008â2009 John R. Wooden Award Preseason Top 50 List | accessdate=2009-03-07 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hFGiYkgT|archivedate=2009-06-02|deadurl=no}} The list is composed of 50 student athletes who, based on 2007-08's individual performance and team records, are the early frontrunners for college basketball's most coveted trophy. These top 50 candidates are returning players. Transfers, freshmen, and medical red-shirts are not eligible for this preseason list, but will be evaluated and considered for both the Midseason Top 30 list and the National Ballot. The ACC was represented by Boston College's Tyrese Rice, Duke's Gerald Henderson and [[Kyle Singler]], Miamiâs Jack McClinton, North Carolina's Tyler Hansbrough, [[Wayne Ellington]] and Ty Lawson and Wake Forestâs [[James Johnson (basketball)|James Johnson]]. In the 2007â08 season, North Carolinaâs Hansbrough became the 12th ACC Player to earn Wooden National Player of the Year Award.{{cite web | url=http://www.theacc.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/111308aab.html | work=Men's Basketball | publisher=TheACC.com | title=Eight ACC Players on Wooden Award Preseason List | accessdate=2009-03-07 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hFGixra3|archivedate=2009-06-02|deadurl=no}} ==Regular season== '''November'''
In November, nine ACC teams participated in eight regular season tournaments across the United States. Four ACC teams claimed championships. {| class="wikitable" ! Name || Dates || Num. teams || Championship |- | [[Coaches Vs. Cancer Classic|2k Sports Classic]] | Nov. 10â21 |
16 | '''[[2008-09 Duke Blue Devils men's basketball team|Duke]]''' 71 vs. [[2008-09 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team|Michigan]] 57 |- | [[Charleston Classic]] | Nov. 14â16 |
8 | '''[[Clemson Tigers men's basketball|Clemson]]''' 76 vs. [[Temple Owls men's basketball|Temple]] 72 |- | [[Maui Invitational Tournament|Maui Invitational]] | Nov. 24â26 |
8 | '''[[2008â09 North Carolina Tar Heels men's basketball team|UNC]]''' 102 vs. [[2008â09 Notre Dame Fighting Irish men's basketball team|Notre Dame]] 87 |- | [[76 Classic]] | Nov. 27â30 |
8 | '''[[2008â09 Wake Forest Demon Deacons men's basketball team|Wake Forest]]''' 87 vs. [[2008â09 Baylor Bears men's basketball team|Baylor]] 74 |} On November 11, Dukeâs [[Mike Krzyzewski]] moved into fifth place on the NCAAâs all-time win list with his 805th career victory, a 97â54 win over [[Georgia Southern Eagles|Georgia Southern]]. On November 16, Virginiaâs [[Sylven Landesberg]] has 28 points, eight rebounds and eight assists as the Cavaliers beat [[Virginia Military Institute|VMI]] 107- 97. Landesbergâs 28 points tied the second-highest total by an ACC freshman in his college debut. On November 21, With Marylandâs 89â74 overtime win over [[The University of Vermont|Vermont]], [[Gary Williams]] became only the third coach in league history to reach 400 career victories while coaching in the ACC. On November 21, Virginiaâs Sylven Landesberg netted a game-high 22 points in the Cavaliersâ 68â66 win over [[Radford University|Radford]] and became only the second freshman in ACC history to score 20 points in each of his first three games. Georgia Techâs [[Kenny Anderson (basketball)|Kenny Anderson]] scored 20 or more points in each of his first six games as a freshman in 1989â90. On November 30, [[Ty Lawson]] had 22 points as No. 1 North Carolina beat [[University of North Carolina at Asheville|UNC-Asheville]] 116â48. The 68-point win margin was the largest in the ACC since a 75-point Maryland win over [[North Texas Mean Green men's basketball|North Texas State]] (132â57) on Dec. 23, 1998, and tied for the seventh largest margin ever in ACC history.
'''December'''
On Wednesday, December 3, The ACC won its 10th-straight [[ACCâBig Ten Challenge]] by winning six of the eleven matchups. The series was highlighted by the 98â63 victory of No. 1 North Carolina over No. 12 Michigan State at [[Ford Field]] in what was dubbed as "[[Basketbowl|Basketbowl II]]". On December 23, Boston Collegeâs [[Corey Raji]] was a perfect 12-for-12 from the field and scored a career-high 26 points in a 99â61 win over [[Maine Black Bears|Maine]]. Rajiâs performance tied him for the second-best single game performance in ACC history. UNCâs [[Brad Daugherty (basketball)|Brad Daugherty]] holds the ACC single-game field proficiency mark making all 13 of his shots versus [[2008â09 UCLA Bruins men's basketball team|UCLA]] back on Nov. 24, 1985. On December 30, NC State sophomore [[Tracy Smith]] came off the bench to score a career-high 31 points in the Wolfpackâs 88â68 win over visiting [[Towson Tigers|Towson]]. Smithâs 31 points set a school record and tied for the third-highest point total by a non-starter in ACC history.
'''January'''
On January 3, [[Jeff Teague]] had a game-high 30 points and [[James Johnson (basketball)|James Johnson]] adds 22 points and 15 rebounds as sixth ranked Wake Forest snapped the nationâs longest home court winning streak at 53 with a 94â87 win at [[BYU Cougars men's basketball|BYU]] before a crowd of 26,096. On January 19, 16â0 Wake Forest took over the No. 1 spot in the AP poll and became the second ACC team to be ranked No. 1 in both the writers and coachesâ polls. With the Deacons assuming the top spot in his 46th game as a head coach, [[Dino Gaudio]] became the third-fastest ACC head coach to have his team voted #1. On January 26, 18â1 Duke became the third ACC team this season to be ranked No. 1 in the AP poll, marking the second time in ACC annals and the fourth time in AP poll history that three different teams from the same conference have been ranked No. 1 in the same season. On January 31, In only the second-ever meeting between brothers in an ACC game, the Aminu brothers ([[Alade Aminu|Alade]] and [[Al-Farouq Aminu|Al-Farouq]]) combine for 27 points and 24 rebounds as Georgia Tech upsets No. 4 Wake Forest 76â74 in Atlanta. Al-Farouq had 17 points, 11 rebounds and five steals for the Deacons while Alade had 10 points, 13 rebounds for the Jackets.
'''February'''
On February 5, midway through the 2009 college basketball season, the [[Los Angeles Athletic Club]]'s John R. Wooden Award Committee selected the top 30 candidates for the [[John R. Wooden Award]], the nation's most coveted college basketball honor. The list is composed of the players who will compete for this season's player of the year award, the midseason list is based on individual player performance and team records during the first half of the season. The ACC was represent by North Carolina's Tyler Hansbrough, Ty Lawson, Duke's Gerald Henderson, Kyle Singler and Wake Forest's [[Jeff Teague]]. Teague was one of nine players who were selected for the midseason list who were not selected in the preseason.{{cite web | url=http://woodenaward.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/020509aai.html | work= | publisher=Wooden Award | title=John R. Wooden Award 2008â09 Midseason Top 30 Candidates Announced | accessdate=2009-03-07 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hFGjO4Cu|archivedate=2009-06-02|deadurl=no}} On February 15, [[Ty Lawson]] had 21 points and four assists and [[Wayne Ellington]] added 15 points and 10 rebounds in North Carolinaâs 69â65 win at Miami. With the win, UNCâs [[Roy Williams (coach)|Roy Williams]]â became the winningest coach through his first 200 games at an ACC school. On February 21, [[Greivis Vasquez]] posted Marylandâs first [[triple-double]] since 1987 as the Terps overcame a 16-point second-half deficit to beat No. 3 North Carolina 88â85 in overtime, ending the Tar Heelsâ 10-game win streak. In posting Marylandâs third ever triple double, Vasquez had a career-high 35 points, 11 rebounds and 10 assists. Vasquezâs 35 points set a record for the most ever by an ACC player recording a triple-double. On February 22, In North Carolinaâs 104â74 win over Georgia Tech, the Tar Heelsâ Tyler Hansbrough made all eight of his [[free throws]] and became the NCAA career leader in free throws made with 907. Hansbrough broke Wake Forest's [[Dickie Hemric]]'s record set in 1955 with his 906th free throw with 14:54 to play in the second half.
'''March'''
On March 7, Miamiâs [[Jack McClinton]] was a perfect 16-for-16 from the free throw line and scored a game-high 24 points as the Hurricanes overcame a nine-point halftime deficit enroute to a 72â64 win over visiting NC State. McClintonâs 16-for-16 effort tied for the fourth-best single-game mark in league history. ==Rankings== {| class="wikitable" style="white-space:nowrap;font-size:95%;" |- ! RD2-score1=69 | RD2-seed2= 3 | RD2-team2='''Duke''' | RD2-score2='''79''' }} The third-seeded Duke Blue Devils defeated fourth-seeded Florida State 79â69 in the title ACC Championship game on Sunday, March 15, giving Duke its ninth ACC crown in 12 years. Duke also tied North Carolina for most tournament championships with 17. Duke's [[Jon Scheyer]] was named the tournament [[Most Valuable Player|MVP]]. ===NCAA Tournament=== {{Main|2009 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament}}

All times are Eastern |} [[Ty Lawson]] was the South regional [[MVP]] and he was joined on the All-regional team by teammates [[Danny Green (basketball)|Danny Green]] and [[Tyler Hansbrough]].{{cite web|url=http://www.memphisflyer.com/memphis/Content?oid=oid%3A57976|title=NCAA South Regional: North Carolina 72, Oklahoma 60|accessdate=2009-03-31|date=2009-03-29|work=[[Memphis Flyer]]|author=Murtaugh, Frank}} The first-seeded North Carolina Tarheels defeated third-seeded Michigan State 89â72 in the title NCAA Championship game on Monday, April 6, giving North Carolina its second NCAA crown in four years. It was North Carolina's fifth national championship. North Carolina's Wayne Ellington was named the Final Four's Most Outstanding Player. ===National Invitation Tournament=== {{Main|2009 National Invitation Tournament}} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%" |- align="left" !Team !Seed !Round !Date !Time !Opponent# !Site !TV !Result !Attendance |- |rowspan=2|'''[[2008â09 Virginia Tech Hokies men's basketball team|Virginia Tech]]''' (1â1) |rowspan=2|

Williams]] â Wake Forest '''Honorable Mention:''' [[Ty Lawson]] â North Carolina, [[Gani Lawal]] â Georgia Tech, [[Courtney Fells]] â NC State, [[Gerald Henderson]] â Duke '''All-ACC Academic team'''
To be eligible for consideration, a student-athlete must have earned a 3.00 grade point average for the previous semester and maintained a 3.00 cumulative average during his academic career. Four players â McClinton, Paulus, Duke's Brian Zoubek and Virginia's Jerome Meyinsse â are repeaters from previous league all-academic teams. McClinton and Paulus were named to the team for the third time in their careers, while Zoubek and Meyinsse are two-time selections.{{cite web | url=http://www.theacc.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/030609aaa.html | work=Men's Basketball | publisher=TheACC.com | title=Miami's Jack McClinton and Duke's Greg Paulus Headline the 2009 All-Atlantic Coast Conference Academic Men's Basketball Team | accessdate=2009-03-06 }} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%" ! Name || School|| Year || Hometown || Major |- | [[Jack McClinton]] | Miami | SR | [[Baltimore, MD]] | Sport Administration |- | [[Jerome Meyinsse]] | UVa | JR | [[Baton Rouge, LA]] | Economics |- | [[Greg Paulus]] | Duke | SR | [[Syracuse, NY]] | Political Science |- | [[Tanner Smith (basketball)|Tanner Smith]] | Clemson | FR | [[Alpharetta, GA]] | Pre-Business |- | [[Tunji Soroye]] | UVa | SR | [[Ibadan|Dugbe Ibadan]], [[Nigeria]] | Education |- | [[Johnny Thomas (basketball)|Johnny Thomas]] | NC State | [[File:Redshirt.svg|15px]]FR | [[Morehead City, NC]] | Sport Management |- | [[Tyler Zeller]] | North Carolina | FR | [[Washington, IN]] | Business Administration |- | [[Brian Zoubek]] | Duke | JR | [[Haddonfield, NJ]] | History |} ==National awards & honors== ===NABC=== On March 5, the [[National Association of Basketball Coaches]] announced their Division I AllâDistrict teams, recognizing the nationâs best menâs collegiate basketball [[student-athlete]]s. Selected and voted on by member coaches of the NABC, 240 student-athletes, from 24 districts were chosen. The selection on this list are then eligible for the State Farm Coachesâ Division I All-America teams to be announced at the 2009 NABC Convention in Detroit. The following list represents the ACC players chosen to the list. All ACC schools are within District 2.{{cite web | url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/nabc/genrel/auto_pdf/D1all-district09.pdf | work= | publisher=National Association of Basketball Coaches | title=National Association of Basketball Coaches Announces 2009 Division I All-District Teams | accessdate=2009-03-05 |author=steven |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hFGiBe27|archivedate=2009-06-02|deadurl=no}}
{{Col-begin}} {{Col-1-of-2}} '''First Team''' *[[Tyler Hansbrough]] â North Carolina *[[Jeff Teague]] â Wake Forest *[[Toney Douglas]] â Florida State *[[Jack McClinton]] â Miami *[[Ty Lawson]] â North Carolina {{Col-2-of-2}}'''Second Team''' *[[Tyrese Rice]] â Boston College *[[Gerald Henderson, Jr.|Gerald Henderson]] â Duke *[[Trevor Booker]] â Clemson *[[Kyle Singler]] â Duke *[[AD Vassallo]] â Virginia Tech {{Col-end}} ===USBWA=== On March 10, the [[United States Basketball Writers Association|U.S. Basketball Writers Association]] released its 2008â09 Men's All-District Teams, based on voting from its national membership. There are nine regions from coast to coast and a player and coach of the year are selected in each. The following is each ACC player selected within their respective regions.{{cite web | url=http://www.sportswriters.net/usbwa/news/2009/alldistrict090310.html | work= | publisher=[[United States Basketball Writers Association|U.S. Basketball Writers Association]] | title=USBWA NAMES 2008â09 MEN'S ALL-DISTRICT TEAMS | accessdate=2009-03-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hFGjmw9a|archivedate=2009-06-02|deadurl=no}} {{Col-begin}} {{Col-1-of-3}}'''District I''' (ME, VT, NH, RI, MA, CT)
'''All-District Team''' *[[Tyrese Rice]], Boston College *[[Joe Trapani]], Boston College {{Col-2-of-3}}'''District III''' (VA, NC, SC, MD)
'''Player of the Year''' *[[Ty Lawson]], North Carolina '''Coach of the Year''' *[[Oliver Purnell]], Clemson '''All-District Team''' *[[Trevor Booker]], Clemson *[[Tyler Hansbrough]], North Carolina *[[Gerald Henderson, Jr.|Gerald Henderson]], Duke *[[Ty Lawson]], North Carolina *[[Kyle Singler]], Duke *[[Jeff Teague]], Wake *[[Greivis Vasquez]], Maryland {{Col-3-of-3}}'''District IV''' (KY, TN MS, AL, GA, FL)
'''All-District Team''' *[[Toney Douglas]], Florida State {{Col-end}} ===CoSIDA=== On February 5, 2009, the [[College Sports Information Directors of America]] (CoSIDA) and ''[[ESPN The Magazine]]'' selected their Academic All-Americans from throughout college basketball. To be nominated, a [[student-athlete]] must be a starter or important reserve with at least a 3.30 cumulative [[grade point average]] (on a 4.0 scale) at his/her current institution. Nominated athletes must have participated in at least 50 percent of the teamâs games at the position listed on the nomination form (where applicable). No student-athlete is eligible until he has completed one full calendar year at his current institution and has reached sophomore athletic eligibility. In the cases of [[College transfer|transfers]], [[Postgraduate education|graduate students]] and [[Junior college|two-year college]] graduates, the student-athlete must have completed one full calendar year at the nominating institution to be eligible. Nominees in [[graduate school]] must have a cumulative GPA of 3.30 or better both as an undergrad and in grad school. The ACC had two players selected from '''District III''' as first-team Academic All-District selections: [[Greg Paulus]] and [[Brian Zoubek]], both from Duke.{{cite web|url=http://www.cosida.com/documents/2009/2/5/09mensbasketball.pdf|title=2009 Academic All-District Menâs Basketball Teams|accessdate=2009-03-27|date=2009-02-05|work=[[ESPN The Magazine]]|author=lanke |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hFGn92uf|archivedate=2009-06-02|deadurl=no}} Greg Paulus was also selected overall by the CoSIDA as a third-team Academic All-American.{{cite web|url=http://www.cosida.com/documents/2009/2/25/2008-09MBBAAATeams.pdf|title=Brett Winkelman of North Dakota State, MIT's Jimmy Bartolotta Lead ESPN The Magazine's Academic All America Men's Basketball Teams|accessdate=2009-03-27|date=2009-02-25|work=[[ESPN The Magazine]]|author=OâConnell, Dan and Geoff Hassard}} ===All-American=== {{main|2009 NCAA Men's Basketball All-Americans}} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%" !Colspan=2|Consensus All-Americans |- !First Team !Second Team |- |[[Tyler Hansbrough]] â North Carolina |[[Ty Lawson]] â North Carolina
[[Jeff Teague]] â Wake Forest |} To earn "consensus" status, a player must win honors from a majority of the following teams: the [[Associated Press]], the [[USBWA]], [[The Sporting News]] and the [[National Association of Basketball Coaches]]. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%" !Associated Press{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/news/story?id=4027698 |title=Griffin, Hansbrough lead AP first team |author=Associated Press |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=2009-03-30 |accessdate=2009-03-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/collegebasketball/story/11569784|title=2009 AP All-America teams|accessdate=2009-04-01|publisher=CBS Interactive|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hFGnZWB9|archivedate=2009-06-02|deadurl=no}} !NABC !Sporting News[http://www.sportingnews.com/yourturn/viewtopic.php?t=526662 Sporting News 2008â09 College Basketball All-Americans] !USBWA[http://www.kansascity.com/news/breaking_news/story/1089222.html 2009 USBWA All-Americans] |- !colspan=4| First Team |- |[[Tyler Hansbrough]] â North Carolina |[[Tyler Hansbrough]] â North Carolina |[[Tyler Hansbrough]] â North Carolina |[[Tyler Hansbrough]] â North Carolina |- !colspan=4|Second Team |- |valign="top"|[[Ty Lawson]] â North Carolina |[[Ty Lawson]] â North Carolina
